Option C: A national court can refer a question on the validity of the decision of the Board at the request of any natural or legal person.
Option D: A national court can consolidate related proceedings without contacting the court in another Member State.

Question: According to the text, who should compensate any damage resulting from processing that infringes the GDPR?
Option A: Data subjects
Option B: Controllers or processors
Option C: Courts of the Member States
Option D: Public authorities

Question: Which of the following penalties can be imposed for any infringement of Regulation (EU) No 1215/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council?
Option A: Imprisonment
Option B: Community service
Option C: Administrative fines
Option D: Written warning

Question: Which authority has the power to impose administrative fines for infringements of the Regulation mentioned in the text?
Option A: European Parliament
Option B: Council of the European Union
Option C: Competent supervisory authority
Option D: Member States

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the imposition of fines for data protection violations in Denmark and Estonia?
Option A: In Denmark, fines are imposed by the supervisory authority, while in Estonia fines are imposed by national courts.
Option B: Fines in both Denmark and Estonia are always imposed as criminal penalties by national courts.
Option C: In Estonia, fines are imposed by the supervisory authority in a misdemeanour procedure, equivalent to administrative fines imposed in Denmark.
Option D: In Denmark, fines are determined by Member State law, while in Estonia fines are determined by EU regulations.

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding public access to official documents and personal data protection under the GDPR?
Option A: Personal data held by public authorities or bodies should never be publicly disclosed.
Option B: Public access to official documents is not considered to be in the public interest.
Option C: Laws of the Member State to which the data subject is subject should apply in case of exemptions or derogations.
Option D: Directive 2003/98/EC does not affect the level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.

Question: Which of the following is NOT a consideration when processing employees' personal data in the employment context under the provisions mentioned in the text?
Option A: Health and safety at work
Option B: Marketing and advertising purposes
Option C: Equality and diversity in the workplace
Option D: Performance of employment contracts

Question: Which of the following safeguards should be implemented for processing personal data for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes?
Option A: Encryption of data
Option B: Two-factor authentication
Option C: Regular data backups
Option D: Pseudonymisation of the data

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the processing of personal data for archiving purposes?
Option A: The GDPR does not apply to processing personal data for archiving purposes.
Option B: The GDPR applies to processing personal data for archiving purposes, but only for living individuals.
Option C: The GDPR applies to processing personal data for archiving purposes for deceased persons.
Option D: The GDPR applies to processing personal data for archiving purposes, including for public interest records and historical research.

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the processing of personal data for statistical purposes?
Option A: This Regulation does not apply to processing personal data for statistical purposes.
Option B: Personal data processed for statistical purposes must always remain as individual-level data.
Option C: Statistical results from processing personal data are considered aggregate data, not personal data.
Option D: Data subjects have the right to request the deletion of their personal data processed for statistical purposes.

Question: Which regulation provides further specifications on statistical confidentiality for European statistics?
Option A: Regulation (EU) No 536/2014
Option B: Regulation (EC) No 223/2009
Option C: Directive 2001/20/EC
Option D: Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1101/2008

Question: Which regulatory body has the power to adopt acts related to criteria and requirements for certification mechanisms, information presented by standardised icons, and procedures for providing such icons?
Option A: European Parliament
Option B: Council of the European Union
Option C: Commission of the European Communities
Option D: Committee on the Statistical Programmes of the European Communities

Question: Which entity is responsible for ensuring an adequate level of protection of personal data under the Regulation mentioned in the text?
Option A: Data subjects
Option B: Controllers
Option C: Processors
Option D: Supervisory authorities

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the European Data Protection Supervisor is true based on the text provided?
Option A: The European Data Protection Supervisor was not consulted in accordance with any regulation.
Option B: The European Data Protection Supervisor delivered an opinion on 12 July 2002.
Option C: The European Data Protection Supervisor's opinion was requested in accordance with Directive 2002/58/EC.
Option D: The European Data Protection Supervisor delivered an opinion on 7 March 2012.

Question: Which of the following scenarios does the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) NOT apply to?
Option A: Processing of personal data in the course of an activity falling outside the scope of Union law
Option B: Processing of personal data by a natural person in the course of a purely personal or household activity
Option C: Processing of personal data by competent authorities for the prevention, investigation, detection, or prosecution of criminal offenses
Option D: Processing of personal data by a business established in the Union for marketing purposes

Question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the term 'pseudonymisation' as defined in the Regulation?
Option A: Pseudonymisation refers to the process of collecting personal data without any restrictions.
Option B: Pseudonymisation involves the use of personal data to evaluate a person's physical attributes.
Option C: Pseudonymisation means processing personal data in a way that it can no longer be linked to an individual without additional information.
Option D: Pseudonymisation involves sharing personal data without any security measures in place.

Question: Which of the following terms is defined as a breach of security leading to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorized disclosure of, or access to, personal data?
Option A: Controller
Option B: Processor
Option C: Recipient
Option D: Personal data breach

Question: Which of the following types of personal data refers to information about the inherited or acquired genetic characteristics of a natural person that give unique information about their physiology or health?
Option A: Biometric data
Option B: Data concerning health
Option C: Genetic data
Option D: Personal data

Question: Which of the following terms refers to an independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51 of the GDPR?
Option A: Enterprise
Option B: Group of undertakings
Option C: Binding corporate rules
Option D: Supervisory authority

Question: What is the definition of 'relevant and reasoned objection' in the context of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: An objection raised by an individual data subject
Option B: An objection to a draft decision regarding the significance of risks to data subjects' fundamental rights and freedoms
Option C: An objection to the appointment of a Data Protection Officer (DPO)
Option D: An objection to a proposed action or decision by a supervisory authority that impacts data processing activities

Question: Which of the following is NOT a principle outlined in Directive (EU) 2015/1535 for processing personal data?
Option A: Storage limitation
Option B: Integrity and confidentiality
Option C: Data subject's consent
Option D: Accountability

Question: Which of the following scenarios allows for the processing of personal data under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) for legitimate interests pursued by the controller or a third party?
Option A: Processing is based on consent given by the data subject.
Option B: Processing is necessary for the performance of a contract with the data subject.
Option C: Processing is necessary to protect the vital interests of the data subject.
Option D: Processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or a third party.

Question: Which of the following is a condition for obtaining consent according to Article 7 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: Encryption of personal data
Option B: Relationship between data subjects and the controller
Option C: Demonstrating that the data subject has consented
Option D: Processing special categories of personal data

Question: What is a key consideration when assessing whether consent is freely given according to the text provided?
Option A: Age of the data subject
Option B: Performance of a contract
Option C: Type of personal data being processed
Option D: Availability of technology for verification

Question: Which of the following is an exception to the prohibition on processing sensitive personal data under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: The data subject has given explicit consent
Option B: Processing is necessary for marketing purposes
Option C: Processing is carried out by a for-profit corporation
Option D: Processing relates to public data made by the data subject

Question: Which of the following scenarios would constitute lawful processing of personal data under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: Processing for any purpose without consent
Option B: Processing necessary for preventive or occupational medicine
Option C: Processing without any safeguards for data subjects
Option D: Processing for commercial purposes only

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences under the GDPR?
Option A: Processing can be carried out by any organization without any specific safeguards.
Option B: Processing must always require the identification of the data subject by the controller.
Option C: Any comprehensive register of criminal convictions can be kept by private entities.
Option D: Processing must be carried out under the control of official authority or authorized by law with appropriate safeguards.

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the provision of information to data subjects under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: The information must always be provided orally, upon request by the data subject.
Option B: The information should be communicated in a complex and technical manner to ensure understanding.
Option C: The controller can refuse to act on the request of the data subject if unable to identify the data subject.
Option D: The controller must inform the data subject of any delay in responding to their request for information.

Question: Which of the following actions can a controller take if a data subject's request is deemed manifestly unfounded or excessive under the GDPR regulations?
Option A: Charge a reasonable fee for providing the information or communication
Option B: Refuse to act on the request
Option C: Seek legal action against the data subject
Option D: Request additional personal data from the data subject

Question: Which of the following is NOT included in the information that a controller must provide to data subjects under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) to ensure fair and transparent processing?
Option A: The purposes of the processing for which the personal data are intended
Option B: The legal basis for the processing
Option C: The legitimate interests pursued by the data subject
Option D: The recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data

Question: Which of the following is a requirement under Article 14 of the GDPR when personal data have not been obtained from the data subject?
Option A: Providing information on automated decision-making
Option B: Informing the data subject of the purpose of further processing
Option C: Disclosing the identity and contact details of the controller
Option D: Offering meaningful information about the logic involved in profiling

Question: Which of the following information must the controller provide to the data subject to ensure fair and transparent processing of personal data?
Option A: The period for which the personal data will be stored
Option B: The color of the data subject's hair
Option C: The data subject's favorite food
Option D: The weather forecast for the day

Question: Which of the following scenarios exempts a controller from providing information to a data subject prior to further processing of personal data under Article 15?
Option A: The data subject already has the information
Option B: It is impossible to provide the information
Option C: It is required by Union or Member State law
Option D: The personal data must remain confidential under professional secrecy

Question: Which of the following rights does a data subject have under GDPR regarding their personal data?
Option A: The right to request a copy of their personal data undergoing processing
Option B: The right to request the controller charge a fee for providing a copy of their personal data
Option C: The right to request the controller not disclose any information about their personal data
Option D: The right to request automated decision-making without any explanation

Question: Which of the following is a valid ground for a data subject to request the erasure of personal data according to Article 17 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: The personal data are no longer necessary for the purposes for which they were collected.
Option B: The data subject withdraws consent for processing based on legitimate grounds.
Option C: The data subject objects to the processing due to personal preferences.
Option D: The personal data have been collected in relation to the offer of financial services.

Question: Which of the following is a valid reason for a data subject to obtain restriction of processing of their personal data according to Article 18 of the GDPR?
Option A: The data subject simply does not want their personal data to be processed
Option B: The controller no longer needs the personal data for processing purposes
Option C: The data subject wants to prevent the controller from verifying the accuracy of the personal data
Option D: The processing is required for the establishment, exercise, or defense of legal claims

Question: What is the purpose of the right to data portability as outlined in Article 20 of the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: To inform data subjects about recipients of their personal data
Option B: To restrict processing of personal data
Option C: To rectify or erase personal data
Option D: To allow data subjects to receive and transfer their personal data between controllers

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the right to object in Article 21 is true?
Option A: The data subject can only object to processing for direct marketing purposes.
Option B: The data subject can object to processing for direct marketing purposes and automated individual decision-making.
Option C: The data subject cannot object to processing of personal data based on Article 6(1).
Option D: The data subject can only object to processing for scientific or historical research purposes.

Question: Which of the following scenarios would NOT require human intervention according to the text?
Option A: Decision necessary for entering into a contract
Option B: Decision authorized by Union or Member State law with suitable safeguards
Option C: Decision based on the data subject's explicit consent
Option D: Decision based on special categories of personal data without suitable safeguards

Question: Which of the following is considered a legitimate purpose for processing personal data under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: Marketing and advertising purposes
Option B: Research and statistical analysis
Option C: Personal data trading
Option D: Prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties

Question: Which of the following is a key requirement for controllers to ensure compliance with data protection regulations?
Option A: Implementing appropriate data protection policies
Option B: Adhering to approved codes of conduct
Option C: Using encryption for all data processing activities
Option D: Implementing data protection principles such as data minimization

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding joint controllers under the GDPR?
Option A: Joint controllers are not required to determine their respective responsibilities for compliance.
Option B: The arrangement between joint controllers must not reflect their roles and relationships with data subjects.
Option C: Data subjects are unable to exercise their rights against each of the joint controllers.
Option D: Joint controllers must determine their respective responsibilities for compliance and may designate a contact point for data subjects.

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the designation of a representative by a controller or processor under the European Union's data protection regulations is true?
Option A: The representative must be established in a Member State where the processing activities take place.
Option B: The designation of a representative by the controller or processor nullifies any legal actions that could be taken against them.
Option C: The processor can engage another processor without prior authorization from the controller.
Option D: The representative is mandated to address all issues related to processing, including legal compliance.

Question: Which of the following is NOT an obligation of a data processor as specified in the text?
Option A: Processes personal data only on documented instructions from the controller
Option B: Ensures confidentiality of persons authorized to process the data
Option C: Takes all measures required pursuant to Article 32
Option D: Respects the conditions for engaging another processor

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the obligations of processors in terms of data protection under the EU regulations?
Option A: A processor is not required to inform the controller if they believe an instruction infringes data protection provisions.
Option B: If a processor engages another processor for processing activities, the initial processor is not liable for the other processor's obligations.
Option C: Adherence to an approved code of conduct or certification mechanism cannot be used to demonstrate sufficient guarantees for data protection.
Option D: The Commission may establish standard contractual clauses for matters related to data protection obligations between controllers and processors.

Question: Which of the following is a requirement under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) regarding the processing of personal data by a processor?
Option A: The processor can determine the purposes and means of processing without the controller's consent.
Option B: The processor is not required to follow instructions from the controller unless mandated by law.
Option C: The processor must maintain a record of processing activities under its responsibility.
Option D: The processor has the authority to transfer personal data to third countries without safeguards.

Question: Which of the following is NOT required to be included in the record of processing activities maintained by a processor on behalf of a controller according to Article 30 of the GDPR?
Option A: Name and contact details of the processor
Option B: Categories of processing carried out on behalf of each controller
Option C: Details of every individual data subject involved
Option D: Description of technical and organizational security measures

Question: What is one of the appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of processing personal data as outlined in Article 32 of the GDPR?
Option A: Regularly testing, assessing, and evaluating the effectiveness of security measures
Option B: Sharing personal data with third-party vendors
Option C: Storing personal data without encryption
Option D: Allowing unauthorized personnel to access personal data

Question: What is required when notifying a personal data breach to the supervisory authority according to Article 33 of the GDPR?
Option A: Notify the supervisory authority within 48 hours
Option B: Describe the consequences of the personal data breach only
Option C: Document the personal data breach only if it is likely to result in a high risk to data subjects
Option D: Describe the nature of the breach, data subjects concerned, consequences, and measures taken

Question: Which of the following conditions would exempt a controller from communicating a personal data breach to the data subject, according to the text provided?
Option A: The controller has implemented appropriate technical and organisational protection measures, including encryption.
Option B: The controller has not taken subsequent measures to mitigate the risk to data subjects.
Option C: The controller is willing to make a public communication instead of informing data subjects directly.
Option D: The supervisory authority has not considered the likelihood of the personal data breach resulting in a high risk.

Question: Which of the following scenarios would require a data protection impact assessment according to the text provided?
Option A: Processing personal data for marketing purposes
Option B: Systematic monitoring of a publicly accessible area on a large scale
Option C: Storing personal data for internal record-keeping
Option D: Sharing personal data with third-party vendors

Question: Which of the following is a requirement for a data protection impact assessment according to the text provided?
Option A: An assessment of the necessity and proportionality of the processing operations in relation to the purposes
Option B: Seeking the views of data subjects or their representatives on the intended processing
Option C: Compliance with approved codes of conduct
Option D: Carrying out a review to assess if processing is performed in accordance with the data protection impact assessment

Question: Which situation requires consultation with the supervisory authority prior to processing according to Article 36?
Option A: When the processing involves a low risk to data subjects
Option B: When a data protection impact assessment indicates a high risk without mitigating measures
Option C: When the controller has identified all risks and implemented mitigation measures
Option D: When the processing operations do not involve any personal data

Question: Which of the following scenarios requires the designation of a data protection officer according to Article 37 of the GDPR?
Option A: Processing carried out by a private company for internal administrative purposes
Option B: Processing of personal data by an online retailer for marketing purposes
Option C: Processing of special categories of data by a healthcare provider
Option D: Processing of personal data by a small business for customer service purposes

Question: Which of the following is a responsibility of a data protection officer according to the text provided?
Option A: Making financial decisions for the organization
Option B: Providing resources necessary to carry out tasks
Option C: Handling customer service issues
Option D: Running marketing campaigns

Question: Which of the following is NOT a task of the data protection officer as outlined in the text?
Option A: Informing and advising the controller or processor and employees about data protection obligations
Option B: Monitoring compliance with data protection regulations and company policies
Option C: Developing codes of conduct for data processing sectors
Option D: Acting as a contact point for the supervisory authority on processing issues

Question: Which of the following is a purpose for which associations and bodies representing controllers or processors may prepare codes of conduct under the GDPR?
Option A: The legitimate interests pursued by controllers in specific contexts
Option B: The collection of personal data
Option C: The pseudonymisation of personal data
Option D: The transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations

Question: Which of the following is a requirement for a code of conduct under the GDPR?
Option A: It must be approved by supervisory authorities
Option B: It must be submitted to the Board for review
Option C: It must be published by the controllers or processors
Option D: It must be registered with the European Commission

Question: Who is responsible for monitoring compliance with a code of conduct according to Article 41 of the text provided?
Option A: The European Commission
Option B: The Data Protection Board
Option C: Accredited bodies approved by the competent supervisory authority
Option D: The controllers and processors themselves

Question: Which of the following actions can a body accredited under Article 41 of the GDPR take in cases of infringement of a code by a controller or processor?
Option A: Impose fines directly on the controller or processor
Option B: Publicly disclose the identity of the controller or processor
Option C: Suspend or exclude the controller or processor from the code
Option D: Issue a warning to the controller or processor

Question: Which of the following statements regarding certification under the GDPR is true?
Option A: Certification is mandatory for all controllers and processors.
Option B: Certification reduces the responsibility of the controller or processor for compliance with the GDPR.
Option C: Certification is issued for an indefinite period without the need for renewal.
Option D: Certification may be renewed for a maximum period of three years if the relevant requirements continue to be met.

Question: Certification bodies issuing and renewing certification related to data protection must be accredited by:
Option A: The European Commission
Option B: The national accreditation body named in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 765/2008
Option C: The United Nations
Option D: The World Health Organization

Question: In the context of data protection certification bodies, what is one of the established procedures required for handling complaints about certification infringements?
Option A: Regularly changing certification criteria
Option B: Issuing certifications without assessment
Option C: Periodic review and withdrawal of certifications
Option D: Keeping complaints confidential

Question: Which body is responsible for revoking the accreditation of a certification body if the conditions for accreditation are not met or actions taken infringe the regulation?
Option A: European Commission
Option B: Competent supervisory authority
Option C: National accreditation body
Option D: Data protection certification board

Question: Which of the following is a key element considered by the Commission when assessing the adequacy of the level of protection for personal data transfers to a third country or international organization?
Option A: The size of the organization
Option B: The number of data subjects involved
Option C: The rule of law, respect for human rights, and effective enforcement of data protection rules
Option D: The marketing strategies of the organization

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the protection of personal data in third countries or international organizations according to the text provided?
Option A: The Commission will review the adequacy of protection every two years.
Option B: The implementing act must specify the supervisory authority in the third country.
Option C: The Commission will only monitor developments in third countries.
Option D: The Commission may repeal a decision if a third country no longer ensures an adequate level of protection.

Question: Which of the following is considered an appropriate safeguard for transferring personal data to a third country or international organisation according to Article 46 of the General Data Protection Regulation?
Option A: A handshake agreement between the parties involved
Option B: Binding corporate rules in accordance with Article 47
Option C: Verbal consent from the data subjects
Option D: A simple email exchange between the parties

Question: Which of the following is considered an appropriate safeguard for transferring personal data to a third country under the GDPR?
Option A: Standard data protection clauses adopted by a supervisory authority
Option B: An approved code of conduct pursuant to Article 40
Option C: Contractual clauses between the controller or processor and the recipient of the personal data
Option D: Binding corporate rules approved by a supervisory authority

Question: What must binding corporate rules specify according to the text provided?
Option A: The structure and contact details of data subjects
Option B: The types of data security measures in place
Option C: The rights of data subjects and how to exercise them
Option D: The mechanisms for ensuring compliance with data protection laws across the organization

Question: Which of the following is not a requirement for ensuring compliance with binding corporate rules according to the text provided?
Option A: Providing information on the rules to data subjects
Option B: Designating a data protection officer
Option C: Implementing complaint procedures
Option D: Conducting data protection audits

Question: Which of the following is NOT a requirement for ensuring compliance with binding corporate rules for the transfer of personal data to third countries?
Option A: Specifying the format and procedures for exchanging information between controllers, processors, and supervisory authorities
Option B: Ensuring appropriate data protection training for personnel with access to personal data
Option C: Obtaining explicit consent from the data subject for the transfer of personal data
Option D: Recognizing and enforcing judgments or decisions from third countries based on international agreements

Question: Which of the following scenarios would NOT be considered a valid legal basis for transferring personal data to a third country or international organization?
Option A: The transfer is necessary for the conclusion or performance of a contract in the interest of the data subject.
Option B: The transfer is necessary for important reasons of public interest.
Option C: The transfer is necessary for the establishment, exercise, or defense of legal claims.
Option D: The transfer is necessary to access public information from a register open to consultation.

Question: Which of the following is a requirement under Article 50 for transferring personal data to third countries or international organizations?
Option A: Notify the Commission of the transfer
Option B: Transfer the entirety of the personal data
Option C: Apply limits to the transfer for public interest reasons
Option D: Document the assessment and safeguards in records

Question: Which of the following statements accurately reflects the role of independent supervisory authorities in enforcing legislation for the protection of personal data?
Option A: Independent supervisory authorities should not engage with stakeholders in discussions related to international cooperation.
Option B: Each Member State is not required to designate a supervisory authority to represent multiple authorities on the Board.
Option C: Supervisory authorities are not expected to contribute to the consistent application of data protection regulations throughout the Union.
Option D: Supervisory authorities are required to act with complete independence in performing their tasks and exercising their powers.

Question: Which of the following is a requirement for members of supervisory authorities in the context of cybersecurity?
Option A: Seek instructions from external sources
Option B: Engage in incompatible occupations during their term of office
Option C: Have qualifications, experience, and skills in the protection of personal data
Option D: Be subject to financial control that affects their independence

Question: Which of the following conditions must be met for a member to be dismissed from a supervisory authority according to the text provided?
Option A: Poor performance in duties
Option B: Failure to attend meetings regularly
Option C: Serious misconduct or failure to meet required conditions
Option D: Disagreement with other members

Question: Which supervisory authority is competent to act as the lead supervisory authority for cross-border processing under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: Supervisory authority of any Member State
Option B: Supervisory authority of the main establishment of the controller or processor
Option C: Supervisory authority of the Member State where the complaint is lodged
Option D: Supervisory authority of the court acting in its judicial capacity

Question: Which of the following tasks is NOT the responsibility of each supervisory authority under the GDPR?
Option A: Enforcing the application of the Regulation
Option B: Promoting public awareness and understanding of data protection risks
Option C: Providing investment advice to data subjects
Option D: Handling complaints lodged by data subjects and investigating them

Question: Which of the following tasks is NOT within the scope of responsibilities for a supervisory authority under the GDPR?
Option A: Conduct investigations on the application of the Regulation
Option B: Monitor relevant developments impacting personal data protection
Option C: Issue standard contractual clauses and provisions
Option D: Conduct periodic reviews of data protection certifications

Question: Which of the following is a corrective power that each supervisory authority has according to Article 58 of the GDPR?
Option A: Issuing warnings to data subjects
Option B: Charging excessive fees for data access requests
Option C: Refusing to act on data access requests without justification
Option D: Notifying the controller or processor of an alleged infringement

Question: Which of the following is a power of a supervisory authority under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: Issuing reprimands to data subjects
Option B: Ordering the controller to comply with data subject requests
Option C: Ordering the processor to issue a certification
Option D: Imposing administrative fines

Question: Which of the following is a power conferred on the supervisory authority according to the text provided?
Option A: Issuing certifications and approving criteria of certification
Option B: Conducting audits on data processors
Option C: Approving software updates for data protection
Option D: Enforcing cybersecurity best practices

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding cooperation between the lead supervisory authority and other supervisory authorities concerned, as outlined in Article 60 of the Journal of the European Union?
Option A: The lead supervisory authority is not required to communicate relevant information to other supervisory authorities concerned.
Option B: The lead supervisory authority may conduct joint operations without informing other supervisory authorities concerned.
Option C: If any other supervisory authority expresses a relevant and reasoned objection to a draft decision, the lead supervisory authority must submit the matter to the consistency mechanism.
Option D: The lead supervisory authority is not obligated to take into account the views of other supervisory authorities concerned.

Question: In the context of GDPR compliance, what action is required of the controller or processor after being notified of a decision by the lead supervisory authority?
Option A: Disregard the decision
Option B: Challenge the decision in court
Option C: Take necessary measures to ensure compliance with the decision
Option D: Inform other controllers or processors of the decision

Question: Which of the following statements about mutual assistance between supervisory authorities under the GDPR is true?
Option A: Supervisory authorities are not required to provide each other with relevant information and mutual assistance.
Option B: Requests for assistance do not need to include the purpose of and reasons for the request.
Option C: The requested supervisory authority can refuse to comply with a request if it deems the request unnecessary.
Option D: Each supervisory authority must reply to a request from another supervisory authority within one month.

Question: Which of the following statements regarding mutual assistance among supervisory authorities is true?
Option A: Requested supervisory authorities may charge a fee for any action taken.
Option B: Requested supervisory authorities are not required to provide reasons for any refusal to comply with a request.
Option C: Requested supervisory authorities shall supply information requested by other supervisory authorities using a non-standard format.
Option D: If a supervisory authority does not provide information within one month, the requesting authority may adopt a provisional measure.

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding joint operations involving supervisory authorities in the European Union?
Option A: Only one supervisory authority is allowed to participate in joint operations.
Option B: Joint operations can only be conducted within the same Member State.
Option C: A significant number of data subjects in more than one Member State must be substantially affected for joint operations to take place.
Option D: Multiple supervisory authorities from different Member States can be involved in joint operations.

Question: Which mechanism is established to ensure the consistent application of the Regulation throughout the Union?
Option A: Supervisory authorities working independently
Option B: Commission oversight only
Option C: Consistency mechanism
Option D: Data protection impact assessment

Question: Which of the following tasks falls under the responsibilities of the Board as outlined in the text?
Option A: Approving data processing agreements
Option B: Reviewing advertising campaigns for compliance with data protection laws
Option C: Approving criteria for accreditation of certification bodies
Option D: Approving software updates for cybersecurity measures

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the decision-making process outlined in the text?
Option A: The Chair of the Board must inform the members of the Board and the Commission using a standardized format.
Option B: The competent supervisory authority can adopt its draft decision within any period it deems necessary.
Option C: The supervisory authority must always follow the opinion of the Board without question.
Option D: If the supervisory authority does not intend to follow the opinion of the Board, Article 65(1) will apply.

Question: Which entity has the authority to communicate to the Board if a competent supervisory authority does not request the opinion of the Board in certain cases under the EU Regulation?
Option A: Commission
Option B: Any supervisory authority concerned
Option C: The lead supervisory authority
Option D: All of the above

Question: Which of the following statements about the urgency procedure under Article 66 is true?
Option A: The validity of provisional measures cannot exceed one month.
Option B: Final measures can be adopted by a supervisory authority without any communication to other authorities.

Option D: Encryption of sensitive information

Question: Which entity should be considered a supervisory authority concerned according to the GDPR regulation?
Option A: The supervisory authority of the Member State where the processor has its main establishment
Option B: The supervisory authority of the Member State where the controller has its main establishment
Option C: The supervisory authorities of the Member State where the processor has one or more establishments
Option D: The supervisory authority of the Member State where the data subject resides

Question: Which principle of data processing emphasizes the need for clear and easily accessible information for data subjects, including details on the identity of the data controller, purposes of processing, risks, rules, safeguards, and rights?
Option A: Principle of Integrity and Confidentiality
Option B: Principle of Data Minimization
Option C: Principle of Transparency
Option D: Principle of Accountability

Question: Which of the following is a legitimate basis for processing personal data according to the text?
Option A: Consent of the data processor
Option B: Compliance with legal obligations
Option C: Marketing purposes
Option D: Random selection

Question: Which of the following scenarios would likely indicate that consent for personal data processing was not freely given?
Option A: The data subject is fully informed about the identity of the controller and the processing purposes.

Option C: The data subject is able to give separate consent to different processing operations.

Question: Which of the following is NOT a specification established by the Regulation governing the lawfulness of personal data processing?
Option A: Determining the controller
Option B: Specifying the purpose limitations
Option C: Setting the maximum internet speed
Option D: Determining the storage period

Question: Which of the following situations may constitute a legitimate interest for a data controller?
Option A: Processing personal data without any relationship with the data subject
Option B: Processing personal data without the data subject's consent
Option C: Processing personal data for direct marketing purposes
Option D: Processing personal data for purposes unrelated to the controller's activities

Question: Which of the following entities is considered to have a legitimate interest in ensuring network and information security as described in the text?
Option A: Computer security incident response teams (CSIRTs)
Option B: Social media platforms
Option C: Marketing agencies
Option D: Online gaming companies

Question: Which of the following factors should a controller consider to determine the compatibility of further processing of personal data?
Option A: The color of the data subject's car
Option B: The consequences of the intended further processing for data subjects
Option C: The controller's favorite movie
Option D: The weather on the day of data collection

Question: Which of the following types of personal data are considered particularly sensitive and require specific protection under data protection regulations?
Option A: Social media activity
Option B: Biometric data
Option C: Shopping preferences
Option D: Email address

Question: Which of the following is a valid reason for allowing derogations from data protection rules, as mentioned in the text?
Option A: Marketing purposes
Option B: Scientific research purposes
Option C: Personal data trading
Option D: Social media tracking

Question: Which of the following is true regarding the processing of special categories of personal data concerning health, as per Regulation (EC) No 1338/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council?
Option A: Consent of the data subject is always required for processing such data.
Option B: Member States are not allowed to introduce further conditions or limitations on processing genetic data.
Option C: Data concerning health can be freely processed by third parties such as employers or insurance companies.
Option D: Suitable and specific measures should be in place to protect the rights and freedoms of natural persons for processing data concerning health for public interest purposes.

Question: Which of the following statements regarding personal data processing is true according to the text?
Option A: Controllers must always acquire additional information to identify data subjects.
Option B: Political parties are not permitted to compile personal data on people's political opinions.
Option C: The principle of transparency requires information to be complex and difficult to understand.
Option D: Personal data processing may be permitted for reasons of public interest in certain circumstances.

Question: Which of the following is NOT a requirement under the GDPR regarding data subject rights facilitation?
Option A: Providing mechanisms for requesting access to personal data
Option B: Responding to data subject requests within one month
Option C: Using complex and technical language in communication with children
Option D: Informing the data subject about the purposes of data processing

Question: What should a controller do when intending to process personal data for a purpose other than that for which they were collected?
Option A: Provide the data subject with information after the processing has been completed
Option B: Inform the data subject at the time of collection from the data subject
Option C: Inform the data subject after the personal data have been disclosed to another recipient
Option D: Provide general information to the data subject without specifying the purpose

Question: Which of the following rights allows a data subject to know and obtain communication regarding the purposes for which personal data are processed, recipients of personal data, and the logic involved in any automatic data processing?
Option A: Right to data portability
Option B: Right to be forgotten
Option C: Right to rectification
Option D: Right to access

Question: Which of the following scenarios would justify a data subject's right to have personal data erased under the GDPR?
Option A: The personal data is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation
Option B: The personal data is required for scientific research purposes
Option C: The data subject has withdrawn consent for processing the personal data
Option D: The personal data is used for archiving purposes

Question: Which of the following methods could be used to restrict the processing of personal data in automated filing systems?
Option A: Moving the data to another processing system temporarily
Option B: Making the data unavailable to users
Option C: Removing published data from a website temporarily
Option D: All of the above

Question: Which of the following statements regarding data subject rights under the GDPR is true?
Option A: A data subject has the right to erase personal data provided for the performance of a contract.
Option B: A data subject can only object to processing of personal data if it violates public interest.
Option C: A data subject has the right to have personal data transmitted directly from one controller to another where technically feasible.
Option D: A data subject cannot object to processing of personal data for direct marketing purposes.

Question: Which of the following scenarios would NOT be considered a violation of data subject rights under GDPR regulations?
Option A: Automatic refusal of an online credit application without any human intervention

Option C: Decision-making based on automated processing for fraud monitoring without explicit consent
Option D: Providing the data subject with the right to challenge a decision reached after automated assessment

Question: Which of the following statements about profiling and automated decision-making is true according to the text provided?
Option A: Profiling and automated decision-making based on special categories of personal data should be allowed without any conditions.
Option B: The controller does not need to implement any technical or organizational measures to ensure accuracy in personal data processing.
Option C: Profiling is subject to the rules of the Regulation governing the processing of personal data, and restrictions may be imposed by Union or Member State law.
Option D: The controller is not required to consider the potential risks to the interests and rights of the data subject when processing personal data.

Question: What is one of the potential risks to the rights and freedoms of individuals resulting from personal data processing, as outlined in the provided text?
Option A: Discrimination
Option B: Identity theft
Option C: Loss of confidentiality
Option D: All of the above

Question: Which of the following types of personal data processing is considered to pose a high risk to the rights and freedoms of individuals according to the text provided?
Option A: Processing of educational history
Option B: Processing of shopping preferences
Option C: Processing of genetic data
Option D: Processing of favorite sports

Question: What measures should be taken to ensure compliance with data protection regulations?
Option A: Maximizing the processing of personal data
Option B: Encrypting personal data as soon as possible
Option C: Keeping data processing functions and activities opaque
Option D: Encouraging data subjects to monitor data processing

Question: When should a controller or processor designate a representative according to the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: Only if processing activities involve special categories of personal data
Option B: Only if processing activities involve criminal convictions and offences
Option C: Only if processing activities are occasional and unlikely to result in risk to natural persons
Option D: When processing activities involve offering goods or services to data subjects in the Union or monitoring their behavior within the Union

Question: Which of the following is a key requirement for processors to demonstrate compliance with data protection regulations?
Option A: Implementing technical and organisational measures
Option B: Maintaining records of processing activities
Option C: Returning or deleting personal data after processing
Option D: Cooperating with supervisory authorities

Question: Which of the following measures should be implemented to mitigate risks related to data security according to the text?
Option A: Regular software updates
Option B: Use of encryption
Option C: Public disclosure of personal data
Option D: Sharing passwords with colleagues

Question: What is the recommended timeframe for a controller to notify a personal data breach to the supervisory authority, as per the GDPR regulations?
Option A: Not later than 48 hours
Option B: Not later than 24 hours
Option C: Not later than 72 hours
Option D: Not later than 96 hours

Question: Which of the following considerations should be taken into account when notifying a personal data breach according to the text provided?
Option A: Whether the breach was intentional or accidental
Option B: The financial impact of the breach on the organization
Option C: The nature and gravity of the personal data breach and its consequences for the data subject
Option D: The popularity of the organization affected by the breach

Question: Which of the following scenarios would most likely require a data protection impact assessment according to the text provided?
Option A: Processing a small amount of personal data for internal use only
Option B: Large-scale processing operations at a national level affecting a significant number of data subjects
Option C: Processing personal data for marketing purposes only
Option D: Processing personal data for general administrative tasks

Question: Which of the following circumstances may warrant a data protection impact assessment to be broader than a single project?
Option A: Processing personal data from patients or clients by an individual physician
Option B: Establishing a common application or processing platform by public authorities
Option C: Introducing a common application across an industry sector by a single controller
Option D: Carrying out processing activities without consulting the supervisory authority

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the consultation process with the supervisory authority in the context of data protection impact assessments and prior notification:
Option A: The absence of a reaction from the supervisory authority indicates automatic approval.
Option B: The supervisory authority cannot intervene in processing operations.
Option C: The processor should assist the controller in ensuring compliance upon request.
Option D: Consultation with the supervisory authority is not required for legislative or regulatory measures.

Question: What is encouraged by the European Union to enhance transparency and compliance with the data protection regulation?
Option A: Drawing up codes of conduct
Option B: Establishing certification mechanisms and data protection seals
Option C: Consulting relevant stakeholders
Option D: All of the above

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations according to the Regulation mentioned in the text?
Option A: Transfers to third countries and international organisations do not need to comply with the Regulation.
Option B: Member States are not allowed to conclude international agreements involving the transfer of personal data.
Option C: The Commission may decide that a third country offers an adequate level of data protection.
Option D: Personal data can be freely transferred without any conditions to third countries.

Question: When assessing a third country's adequacy for data transfers, what factors should the Commission take into consideration?
Option A: Human rights protection, rule of law, access to justice, and international human rights norms
Option B: Economic stability and trade relations with the EU
Option C: Climate change policies and environmental regulations
Option D: Cultural heritage preservation and tourism initiatives

Question: Which international convention should be taken into account when assessing the level of protection of personal data in third countries?
Option A: Council of Europe Convention of 28 January 1981 for the Protection of Individuals with regard to the Automatic Processing of Personal Data
Option B: United Nations Convention on Cybersecurity
Option C: Asia-Pacific Data Protection Agreement
Option D: World Data Protection Treaty

Question: Which of the following is considered an appropriate safeguard for transferring personal data to a third country without an adequacy decision in compliance with data protection requirements?
Option A: Encryption of the data during transfer
Option B: Obtaining consent from the data subject prior to transfer
Option C: Implementing binding corporate rules or standard data protection clauses
Option D: Notifying the data subject after the transfer has taken place

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the use of standard data-protection clauses in contracts is true?
Option A: Controllers and processors must always use only the standard data-protection clauses without any additional safeguards.
Option B: Controllers and processors are prohibited from including standard data-protection clauses in wider contracts.
Option C: Controllers and processors can add other clauses or additional safeguards as long as they do not contradict the standard contractual clauses or infringe on the data subjects' rights.
Option D: Controllers and processors are not encouraged to provide additional safeguards via contractual commitments.

Question: Which of the following is an example of a situation where data transfers may be considered lawful for important reasons of public interest?
Option A: Sharing personal data for marketing purposes
Option B: Transferring personal data without consent for profit
Option C: Exchanging personal data between financial supervisory authorities for regulatory purposes
Option D: Selling personal data to third-party vendors for advertising

Question: Which of the following scenarios could justify the transfer of personal data to an international humanitarian organization without explicit consent from the data subject?
Option A: Transfer for commercial purposes
Option B: Transfer for marketing activities
Option C: Transfer to comply with international humanitarian law in armed conflicts
Option D: Transfer for data monetization

Question: Which of the following statements best describes the concerns raised in the text regarding data transfers to third countries?
Option A: Third countries' laws and regulations always align perfectly with the data protection standards of the European Union.
Option B: Personal data transfers to third countries may hinder the protection of natural persons' data rights and impede regulatory enforcement.
Option C: Data protection supervisory authorities have unlimited power and resources to oversee cross-border data transfers.
Option D: The extraterritorial application of third countries' laws always enhances the protection of personal data.

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding supervisory authorities in the context of personal data protection?

Option B: Member States can only establish one supervisory authority to oversee personal data protection.

Question: Which of the following is a requirement for the independence of a supervisory authority as per the text provided?

Option B: Appointing members through a non-transparent procedure
Option C: Engaging in incompatible occupations during their term
Option D: Having its own staff subject to the exclusive direction of the supervisory authority

Question: Which of the following is NOT a responsibility of supervisory authorities under the GDPR?
Option A: Monitoring the application of GDPR provisions
Option B: Promoting public awareness of personal data risks and rights
Option C: Needing agreements between Member States for cooperation
Option D: Contributing to the consistent application of GDPR throughout the Union

Question: Which supervisory authority should adopt binding decisions regarding measures under the GDPR when processing substantially affects data subjects in more than one Member State?
Option A: The supervisory authority with the most resources
Option B: The lead supervisory authority
Option C: The data subjects themselves
Option D: Any supervisory authority chosen at random

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the one-stop-shop mechanism under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: The one-stop-shop mechanism applies to all cases of data processing, regardless of whether it is carried out by public authorities or private bodies.
Option B: The lead supervisory authority must always handle the case, regardless of the establishment of the controller or processor.
Option C: The one-stop-shop mechanism does not apply when the processing is carried out by public authorities or private bodies in the public interest.
Option D: The lead supervisory authority has no obligation to consider the establishment of the controller or processor when deciding to handle the case.

Question: What must supervisory authorities ensure when exercising their powers under the GDPR?
Option A: Impartiality, fairness, and efficiency
Option B: Adherence to procedural safeguards, necessity, and proportionality
Option C: Avoidance of superfluous costs and excessive inconveniences
Option D: All of the above

Question: According to the text, in cases where a complaint or possible infringement concerns processing activities of a controller or processor in a specific Member State and does not substantially affect data subjects in other Member States, the supervisory authority receiving the complaint should first seek an amicable settlement with the controller. If unsuccessful, what should the supervisory authority do next?
Option A: Seek assistance from an external cybersecurity firm
Option B: Request intervention from the European Data Protection Board
Option C: Seek an amicable settlement with the data subjects directly
Option D: Exercise its full range of powers

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the cooperation between supervisory authorities under the GDPR?

Option C: The consistency mechanism for cooperation is optional for supervisory authorities.
Option D: The Board can issue legally binding decisions with a simple majority vote.

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the application of provisional measures by a supervisory authority under the GDPR?

Option C: The cooperation mechanism between the lead supervisory authority and supervisory authorities concerned should not be applied in cases of cross-border relevance.
Option D: A supervisory authority should be able to adopt duly justified provisional measures on its territory with a specified period of validity not exceeding three months.

Question: Which entity is responsible for advising the Commission on the level of data protection in third countries or international organizations?

Option C: Data Subject
Option D: Secretariat

Question: Which of the following entities can lodge a complaint on behalf of a data subject with a supervisory authority under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: For-profit organization
Option B: Government agency
Option C: Not-for-profit body with statutory objectives in the public interest
Option D: Data subject themselves

Question: Which of the following is NOT considered within the scope of an effective judicial remedy under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?

Option B: Corrective powers by the supervisory authority
Option C: Opinions issued by the supervisory authority

Question: Which of the following statements regarding legal proceedings related to data processing is true according to the text provided?

Option C: The plaintiff must always bring the action before the courts of the Member State where the data subject resides.

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding liability for data processing under the GDPR?

Option D: Each controller or processor can be held liable for the entire damage caused by the processing.

Option C: The nature, gravity, and duration of the infringement
Option D: The color scheme of the organization's logo

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the imposition of administrative fines under the GDPR?

Option C: The legal systems of all EU Member States allow for administrative fines as set out in the GDPR.

Question: What should Member States implement in cases of serious infringements of the GDPR to ensure compliance with effective and dissuasive penalties?
Option A: Criminal penalties only
Option B: Administrative penalties only
Option C: Both criminal and administrative penalties
Option D: No penalties required

Option C: Directive 2005/36/EC
Option D: Directive 2007/13/EC

Question: Which of the following is true regarding the processing of employees' personal data in the employment context?

Option D: Processing of personal data is only allowed for marketing purposes

Question: Which of the following rights related to personal data processing are mentioned in the text?

Option B: Right to be forgotten and right to data portability
Option C: Right to restriction of processing and right to object

Question: Which of the following scenarios is exempt from the application of this Regulation?

Option B: Processing personal data for historical research purposes
Option C: Processing personal data of deceased persons
Option D: Processing personal data related to political behavior under former totalitarian state regimes

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the processing of personal data for statistical purposes according to the text provided?

Question: What is the purpose of the specific rules mentioned in the text regarding safeguarding professional secrecy obligations in relation to the protection of personal data?
Option A: To enhance data security measures

Option C: To restrict access to personal data for supervisory authorities
Option D: To limit the powers of the controller or processor

Question: Which of the following is NOT a topic covered by the examination procedure for the adoption of implementing acts according to the text provided?

Option B: Arrangements for the exchange of information by electronic means between supervisory authorities
Option C: Procedures for providing standardized icons
Option D: Mutual assistance

Question: Which directive should be repealed by the Regulation mentioned in the text?
Option A: Directive 2002/58/EC
Option B: Directive 95/46/EC
Option C: Regulation (EC) No 45/2001
Option D: Treaty on European Union

Question: Which of the following activities falls outside the scope of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?

Option C: Processing of personal data by competent authorities for criminal investigation purposes
Option D: Processing of personal data for the purpose of free movement within the Union

Question: Which of the following scenarios would NOT fall under the territorial scope of the GDPR?

Option C: Processing of personal data by a controller not established in the Union, but in a place where Member State law applies by virtue of public international law
Option D: Processing of personal data solely for internal purposes within a single Member State

Question: Which of the following terms refers to the automated processing of personal data to evaluate certain personal aspects of a natural person, such as their performance at work, economic situation, health, personal preferences, interests, reliability, behavior, location, or movements?
Option A: Pseudonymisation
Option B: Profiling
Option C: Processing
Option D: Controller

Question: Which of the following definitions refers to a natural or legal person that processes personal data on behalf of the controller?
Option A: Recipient
Option B: Processor
Option C: Third party
Option D: Genetic data

Question: Which of the following is considered as "data concerning health" according to the text?
Option A: Facial images
Option B: Main establishment
Option C: Physical or mental health information
Option D: Data protection policies

Question: Which of the following best describes the term 'supervisory authority' in the context of data protection regulations in the European Union?
Option A: A private organization designated by the data controller
Option B: An external cybersecurity firm hired by the data processor
Option C: An independent public authority established by a Member State
Option D: A data protection officer appointed by the data subject

Question: Which principle of processing personal data is reflected in the requirement to ensure that personal data are accurate and kept up to date?
Option A: Lawfulness, fairness, and transparency
Option B: Purpose limitation
Option C: Data minimisation
Option D: Accuracy

Question: Which of the following is a requirement for ensuring appropriate security of personal data according to the text provided?
Option A: Implementation of the appropriate technical and organizational measures
Option B: Obtaining consent from the data subject for processing
Option C: Performance of a task in the public interest
Option D: Pursuing legitimate interests without considering data subject's rights

Question: Which of the following is a valid basis for processing personal data according to the text provided?
Option A: Consent of the data subject
Option B: International law
Option C: Controller's preference
Option D: Organization's policy

Question: Which of the following factors should a controller consider when determining if processing personal data for a different purpose is compatible with the original purpose, according to Article 23 of the GDPR?
Option A: The color of the data subject's eyes
Option B: The relationship between data subjects and the controller
Option C: The weather conditions at the time of data collection
Option D: The number of social media accounts the data subject has

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the processing of personal data of children for information society services according to the text provided?
Option A: Children below the age of 16 can provide consent on their own.
Option B: Member States must set the minimum age for children's consent to be at least 16 years old.
Option C: The controller is not required to verify parental consent for processing children's personal data.
Option D: Member States may set a lower age for children's consent, provided it is not below 13 years.

Question: Which of the following scenarios is a legitimate basis for processing personal data under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: Sharing personal data without consent for marketing purposes
Option B: Selling personal data to third-party companies
Option C: Processing personal data to protect the vital interests of a data subject who is unable to give consent
Option D: Disclosing personal data to unauthorized individuals

Question: Which of the following scenarios allows for the processing of personal data for reasons of public interest in the area of public health, subject to suitable measures to safeguard data subject rights and freedoms?
Option A: Processing for marketing purposes
Option B: Processing for commercial gain
Option C: Processing for archiving purposes in the public interest
Option D: Processing for personal use

Question: Which of the following scenarios allows for processing of personal data without identification of the data subject under the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: When the controller decides not to comply with the Regulation
Option B: When the data subject requests identification in writing
Option C: When the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law with appropriate safeguards
Option D: When the controller is unable to identify the data subject but proceeds with processing anyway

Question: Which of the following is true regarding the controller's obligations when dealing with data subject requests under Articles 15 to 22 of the GDPR?
Option A: The controller can refuse to act on the request without providing any explanation.
Option B: The controller must provide information on actions taken within two months of receiving the request.
Option C: The controller must inform the data subject of any extensions to the response period and provide reasons for the delay.
Option D: The controller is not responsible for providing information free of charge under any circumstances.

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the provision of information to data subjects under the GDPR?
Option A: The controller is not required to provide any contact details to the data subject.
Option B: Icons must be provided in a non-machine-readable format for easy visibility.
Option C: The controller may request additional information to confirm the identity of the data subject if there are doubts.
Option D: The controller is not required to disclose the purposes of processing personal data.

Question: Which of the following is NOT a necessary piece of information that the controller must provide to the data subject at the time when personal data are obtained, according to the GDPR?
Option A: The period for which the personal data will be stored
Option B: The right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority
Option C: The right to withdraw consent at any time
Option D: The data subject's favorite color

Question: Which of the following information does a controller need to provide to a data subject when personal data have not been obtained from the data subject according to Article 14 of the GDPR?
Option A: Purpose of the processing and legal basis
Option B: Period for which the personal data will be stored
Option C: The data subject's consent for processing
Option D: Identity and contact details of the data protection officer

Question: Which of the following rights does a data subject have under GDPR regulations?
Option A: Right to withdraw consent at any time
Option B: Right to anonymous data processing only
Option C: Right to demand unlimited retention of personal data
Option D: Right to restrict access to personal data

Question: Which of the following scenarios allows for obtaining or disclosing personal data without the data subject's consent?
Option A: Data is being processed for historical research purposes
Option B: Data must remain confidential due to professional secrecy obligations
Option C: Data is being processed for statistical purposes
Option D: Data is being processed in compliance with Union or Member State law

Question: Which right allows a data subject to request the correction of inaccurate personal data without undue delay?
Option A: Right to erasure
Option B: Right to object
Option C: Right to data portability
Option D: Right to rectification

Question: Which of the following scenarios would NOT be a valid reason for requesting erasure of personal data under the GDPR?
Option A: The data subject withdraws consent for processing based on Article 6(1)(a)
Option B: The data subject objects to the processing under Article 21(1) and there are no overriding legitimate grounds
Option C: The personal data have been unlawfully processed
Option D: The personal data have been collected in relation to the offer of information society services referred to in Article 8(1)

Question: Which of the following scenarios allows a data subject to obtain the restriction of processing according to Article 18 of the GDPR?
Option A: The data subject wants to prevent the controller from verifying the accuracy of their personal data.
Option B: The processing is lawful, but the data subject wishes to erase their personal data.
Option C: The controller no longer needs the personal data for processing, but the data subject requires it for legal claims.
Option D: The data subject has given consent to the processing.

Question: Which of the following rights allows a data subject to receive personal data in a machine-readable format and transfer it to another controller without hindrance?
Option A: Right to be forgotten
Option B: Right to object
Option C: Right to data portability
Option D: Right to access

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the right to object to processing of personal data for direct marketing purposes according to the text provided?
Option A: The data subject can only object to processing of personal data for direct marketing purposes in writing.
Option B: The data subject's objection to processing for direct marketing purposes has no impact on further processing of personal data for such purposes.
Option C: The right to object to processing for direct marketing purposes must be explicitly brought to the attention of the data subject at the time of the first communication.
Option D: The data subject can exercise the right to object to processing for direct marketing purposes only through a manual submission.

Question: Under the GDPR, decisions that significantly affect individuals must not be based on special categories of personal data unless certain conditions are met. Which of the following is NOT an acceptable condition for such decisions to be based on special categories of personal data?
Option A: National security
Option B: Explicit consent of the data subject
Option C: Prevention, investigation, detection, or prosecution of criminal offences
Option D: Public health and social security

Question: Which of the following is a responsibility of the controller under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?
Option A: Protection and prosecution of breaches of ethics for regulated professions
Option B: Monitoring, inspection, or regulatory function connected to the exercise of official authority
Option C: Enforcement of civil law claims
Option D: Implementing appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure GDPR compliance
